awd_titl_txt: Functional Consequences of Being Multicellular: Predation by Protozoans on Unicellular vs. Multicellular Choanoflagellates
awd_abstract_narration:
Animal bodies are made up of many cells, but the ancestors of animals were single-celled organisms ("protozoans").  A pivotal step in the evolution of life was the transition from being unicellular to becoming multicellular.  The closest protozoan relatives of animals are aquatic "choanoflagellates", which are unicellular but can also form multicellular colonies.   For multicellularity to evolve, colonies of animal ancestors must have performed functions affecting their survival better than did solitary cells.  This study examines whether unicellular or multicellular choanoflagellates are better able to avoid being eaten by protozoan predators, and the mechanisms involved.  This project at the interface between biology and physics (hydrodynamics of how aquatic predators and prey interact) will give teams of undergraduate students from different majors hands-on research experience and will involve them in interdisciplinary research, which is important because many future discoveries in science and technology will be made at interfaces between different fields. Public outreach includes an interactive online site where citizen scientists can calculate the predation rates on unicellular and multicellular choanoflagellates by different types of predators. Work with women and dyslexics by the PIs will encourage success in science and technology fields. A novel microfluidic system will be developed to determine how performance and mechanisms of predator-prey interactions (usually studied in still water) are affected by realistic patterns of fluctuating shear that microscopic swimmers experience in natural, turbulent water flow.  This system will be useful for studying other aquatic microoganisms interacting with each other in nature.
 
Protozoans, both unicellular and colonial, play important roles in aquatic food webs.  Chonaoflagellates, the closest protozoan relatives of animals, will be used to study mechanisms underlying resistance to predation by uni- vs. multicellular protozoans.  Data about choanoflagellates will also enable informed inferences about the possible role of predation as a selective factor in the evolution of multicellularity.  The origin of multicellular animals from unicellular protozoans represents a pivotal transition in life's history.  This study focuses on resistance to being eaten by protozoan predators (before animals evolved, predators on chonaoflagellates were other protozoans).   Research goals are to:  1) quantify performance differences between unicellular and colonial choanoflagellates in avoiding predation by protozoan predators using different modes of prey capture;  2) elucidate fluid dynamics of interactions between predators and choanoflagellate prey to identify mechanisms underlying performance differences;  3) determine how fluctuating shear encountered by protozoans carried in turbulent water flow in nature affects interactions of unicellular vs. colonial prey with predators.  High-speed videomicrography of predators, prey, and flow-marking microbeads will record interactions of choanoflagellates with different protozoan predators. Digitized protozoan trajectories enable calculation of encounter and predation success rates, and behavioral interactions. Particle tracking velocimetry will quantify instantaneous flow fields produced by predators and prey, and hydrodynamic signals during their interactions.  A novel contribution is development of microfluidic techniques to determine how mechanisms of predator-prey interactions (usually studied in still water) are affected by realistic patterns of fluctuating shear that microscopic swimmers experience in turbulent ambient water flow.

Intellectual merit: 

            The evolutionary origin of multicellular animals from unicellular protozoan ancestors was a pivotal transition in the history of life on earth.  Genetic analyses showed that choanoflagellate protozoans and sponges (primitive animals) are closely related and shared a common ancestor.  Some species of unicellular choanoflagellates also can form multicellular colonies, so we use them to study the process and consequences of becoming multicellular.  By studying these choanoflagellates, we can make informed inferences about the evolution of multicellularity in the ancestors of animals. 

            When multicellularity evolved in the ancestors of animals, natural selection would have favored forms that had greater "fitness" (higher rates of survival and reproduction).  Which tasks that affect fitness could multicellular colonies do better than single cells?  We addressed this question by comparing the performance of unicellular vs. multicellular choanoflagellates in swimming, feeding, and avoiding being eaten by predators.  Our work on the mechanisms responsible for performance differences between single cells and colonies in feeding and avoiding being eaten also provides insights about the dynamics of aquatic ecosystems because both unicellular and colonial protozoans play important roles in aquatic food webs.

            A choanoflagellate has a tiny cell body (1/10,000 inch) and swims by waving a single whip-like flagellum.  The flagellum is surrounded by a "collar" (a picket fence of stick-like microvilli) that catch bacterial prey as a choanoflagellate moves through the water.  Swimming, feeding, and avoiding predation are all tasks that depend on the hydrodynamics of choanoflagellates, so our interdisciplinary research involves both the physics of water flow and the biology of colony formation and protozoan interactions.  We combined laboratory approaches from biology and engineering with mathematical modeling to address our research questions.  

            The focus of this grant was to compare the susceptibility of unicellular choanoflagellates versus multicellular colonies to being eaten by protozoan predators, and to identify the mechanisms responsible. Before animals evolved, the predators on the ancestors of animals and choanoflagellates were other protozoans.  It has long been thought that multicellular colonies might have been too big for those unicellular predators to consume.  The feeding modes of protozoan predators are categorized into functional types:  1) motile raptors hunt prey and actively catch them using cell protrusions;  2) suspension feeders create a feeding current that draws water carrying prey towards their capture surfaces;  3) passive predators eat prey that swim or drift onto their capture surfaces.  We discovered that choanoflagellate colonies produce much larger hydrodynamic signals than do single cells, and that raptorial protozoan predators sense the flow produced by colonies and capture them while ignoring unicellular choanoflagellates (the opposite of what was proposed in the scientific literature). In contrast, we found that ciliate suspension feeders entrain both single cells and colonies in their feeding currents, but reject colonies that are too large to ingest through their gullets.  Our research also revealed that passive protozoan predators feed on colonies and unicellular choanoflagellates at the same rate.  We also studied how specific behaviors of microorganisms interact with the ambient water flow in their natural habitats to affect their feeding success and their movements through the environment. Our earlier research showed that when choanoflagellates form multicellular colonies, it does not improve swimming performance, but does increase the feeding rates of the cells in a colony.  Overall, our results suggest that the ability of the choanoflagellate-like ancestors of animals to switch between being unicellular and multicellular in response to variable aquatic environments (e.g. patchy distribution of bacterial prey, changes in abundance of different the types of predators) might have provided a selective advantage to the ancestors of animals.

 

Broader impacts: 

            A major objective of our project was to provide training for students in interdisciplinary research.  We involved 20 undergraduates (12 women, 8 men) majoring in biology, physics, or engineering, and one biophysics graduate student (male) in the research.  We had students from physical and biological sciences work together in small teams to address specific research questions, and trained them in both laboratory techniques and data analysis.  We had weekly meetings to discuss their discoveries and technical challenges, so they gained experience in group problem-solving, and learned to communicate across disciplines. 

           To increase interest in learning and careers in science we gave talks about our interdisciplinary work at forums to encourage high school students to pursue STEM, and to inspire college STEM students to consider interdisciplinary research.  To disseminate our interdisciplinary results to members of the scientific community in diverse fields, we gave talks about this research to ecologists, fluid dynamicists, engineers, and mathematicians at universities and scientific conferences.

            New technologies we developed for this research include fluidic devices that deliver pulses of water flow mimicking the fluctuating accelerations and shears encountered by microscopic organisms swimming in turbulent ambient water flow, and apparatus for high-speed microvideography of microrganisms in vessels big enough for them to move freely.
